newsitem.title: USA: CSX says its Conrail offer is better.
newsitem.headline: CSX says its Conrail offer is better.

text.p: CSX Corp said on Wednesday that it believes its cash-and-stock merger offer for Conrail Inc is better than the rival bid made earlier today by Norfolk Southern Corp.
"By every measure, the CSX-Conrail merger is superior in economic, operational and public policy terms to the Norfolk Southern non-bid," CSX said in a statement.

"Norfolk Southern's hostile offer comes as no surprise," CSX said in a statement. "It simply does not provide the same long-term value as the strategic CSX-Conrail partnership, which offers Conrail shareholders tax-free equity and the substantial upside potential that only comes from the benefits derived from the merger of CSX and Conrail.
The Norfolk Southern $100-per-share tender offer came just eight days after CSX agreed to acquire Conrial in a cash and stock deal valued at $8.4 billion, or about $92.50 a share.
Norfolk Southern has also asked a federal court to block CSX's intial tender offer for Conrail and also a Conrail shareholders meeting set for November 14.
CSX said that Norfolk Southern's "highly conditional non-bid" would inevitably face serious delay and could not be completed without the approval of the Conrail board.

It added that the provisions of the CSX-Conrail merger agreement specifically preclude in effect the Conrail board of directors' approval of any competing offers before mid-April 1997. It said the CSX cash tender offer would close in November 1996.
It said certain delays involved in the Norfolk Southern offer "severely and negatively impact the present value of its proposal."

"Using a customary discount rate of two percent per month, the Norfolk Southern non-bid is worth less than $90 per Conrail share, far less than Norfolk Southern would have Conrail shareholders believe," CSX said.
